Rational people are usually liberal but always selfish. 
 
 The goal of rationality is happiness. Whatever the contingent political, social, economic, or moral circumstances, the rational man seeks to maximise pleasure and to minimise pain. The woes of the world are of concern to the rational man - because directly or indirectly, they affect his happiness. The self interest of the rational man is, on the principle of reciprocity, served or injured by the satisfactions or suffering in society. It pays the rational man to analyse options and calculate outcomes on the selfish basis that the net result should reduce suffering and thereby maintain or even augment his happiness. 
 
 The liberal man is always rational: irrational liberalism is an oxymoron. Whatever the problem, the liberal will search for a reasoned solution : there will be no religious influence on any such solution. The appliance of science wherever appropriate, is a liberal dogma. In the liberal view, human conduct can be explained, modified, guided or whatever by purely rational deliberations. Liberal people are concerned to remedy every variety of ailment that afflicts the human race. A liberal response to armed conflict, for example, is to seek a negotiated settlement, to avoid violence, to minimise human suffering, and to restore or to achieve a happy equilibrium. It is in the interest of the liberal man to have such concerns and to work for peaceful resolutions of hostilities - whatever their character. Public happiness on the widest possible scale is a liberal aim: the private happiness of the solitary rational individual has an interest in the success of this aim. 
 
 It is possible to be rational and illiberal, but this is a perverted kind of rationalism which dismisses the self interested behaviour that optimises pleasure and avoids pain. 
 
 For my final generalisation, I would assert that liberal people are, by definition, rational people and, whether they admit it or not, they are also selfish people because all rational behaviour is, ultimately, the self interested pursuit of happiness. 
 
 (Here's a quintessential liberal excuse : where I have written liberal "man" in my observations, I also of course include women. Only brevity and a wish to avoid clumsiness of expression have put me on the spot).

The conservative scoffs at all utopian schemes: he/she does not believe that by the power of positive law we can solve all the problems of humanity. Conservatives know that human beings are not perfectible and neither are political arrangements.
 
 What characterises a conservative disposition in politics is nothing to do with natural law, a providential order, or ethics. It is an acceptance of the current way of living combined with the hypothesis that government should be a limited and specific activity - namely the provision and custody of general rules of conduct. The essence of conservatism does not reside in any particular set of principles, but in its appeal to impenitent materialism and scepticism about the power of politicians to give effect to utopian schemes.

The rational man is obviously a calculating agent, and as such he will make a judgment, where conflict of interest arises, that will tend to optimise the total happiness in which he participates.
 
 I have claimed that the rational liberal man desires a reduction of the misery in society (or in the world at large). It should be understood that an essential value at the core of any liberal activity that results in reducing misery and increasing happiness, should be identified as freedom. What I mean by "freedom" is simply the liberty of each individual to pursue his own ends without any unreasoned restraint of his behaviour or censure of his conduct by others. (Note, I qualified the use of restraint). 
 
 It might appear to be a paradox, but the rational regard I have for my own interests, which by definition is selfish, promotes like the "invisible hand" of Adam Smith, the welfare of the world outside my own limited and vulgar perspective. 
 
 Rational, liberal, and selfish might be described as the indispensable attributes of an ideal type of the modern secular human being.
